In mathematics, Abel's theorem for power series relates a limit of a power series to the sum of its coefficients. It is named after Norwegian mathematician Niels Henrik Abel.

Theorem[edit]

Let

G ( x ) = ∑ k = 0 ∞ a k x k {\displaystyle G(x)=\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}x^{k}}

be a power series with real coefficients ak with radius of convergence 1. Suppose that the series

∑ k = 0 ∞ a k {\displaystyle \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}}

converges. Then G(x) is continuous from the left at x = 1 {\displaystyle x=1} , i.e.

lim x → 1 − G ( x ) = ∑ k = 0 ∞ a k . {\displaystyle \lim _{x\to 1^{-}}G(x)=\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}.}

The same theorem holds for complex power series

G ( z ) = ∑ k = 0 ∞ a k z k , {\displaystyle G(z)=\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}z^{k},}

provided that z → 1 {\displaystyle z\to 1} within a Stolz sector, that is, a region of the open unit disk where

| 1 − z | ≤ M ( 1 − | z | ) {\displaystyle |1-z|\leq M(1-|z|)}

for some M. Without this restriction, the limit may fail to exist: for example, the power series

∑ n > 0 z 3 n − z 2 × 3 n n {\displaystyle \sum _{n>0}{\frac {z^{3^{n}}-z^{2\times 3^{n}}}{n}}}

converges to 0 at z = 1, but is unbounded near any point of the form eπi/3n, so the value at z = 1 is not the limit as z tends to 1 in the whole open disk.

Note that G(z) is continuous on the real closed interval [0, t] for t < 1, by virtue of the uniform convergence of the series on compact subsets of the disk of convergence. Abel's theorem allows us to say more, namely that G(z) is continuous on [0, 1].

Remarks[edit]

As an immediate consequence of this theorem, if z is any nonzero complex number for which the series

∑ k = 0 ∞ a k z k {\displaystyle \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}z^{k}}

converges, then it follows that

lim t → 1 − G ( t z ) = ∑ k = 0 ∞ a k z k {\displaystyle \lim _{t\to 1^{-}}G(tz)=\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}z^{k}}

in which the limit is taken from below.

The theorem can also be generalized to account for infinite sums.[citation needed] If

∑ k = 0 ∞ a k = ∞ {\displaystyle \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}=\infty }

then

lim z → 1 − G ( z ) → ∞ . {\displaystyle \lim _{z\to 1^{-}}G(z)\to \infty .}

However, if the series is only known to be divergent, the theorem fails; take for example, the power series for

1 1 + z . {\displaystyle {\frac {1}{1+z}}.}

At z = 1 {\displaystyle z=1} the series is equal to 1 − 1 + 1 − 1 + ⋯ , {\displaystyle 1-1+1-1+\cdots ,} but 1 1 + 1 = 1 2 . {\displaystyle {\tfrac {1}{1+1}}={\tfrac {1}{2}}.}

We also remark the theorem holds for radii of convergence other than R = 1 {\displaystyle R=1} : let

G ( x ) = ∑ k = 0 ∞ a k x k {\displaystyle G(x)=\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}x^{k}}

be a power series with radius of convergence R {\displaystyle R} , and suppose the series converges at x = R {\displaystyle x=R} . Then G ( x ) {\displaystyle G(x)} is continuous from the left at x = R {\displaystyle x=R} , i.e.

lim x → R − G ( x ) = G ( R ) {\displaystyle \lim _{x\to R^{-}}G(x)=G(R)}

Applications[edit]

The utility of Abel's theorem is that it allows us to find the limit of a power series as its argument (i.e. z {\displaystyle z} ) approaches 1 from below, even in cases where the radius of convergence, R {\displaystyle R} , of the power series is equal to 1 and we cannot be sure whether the limit should be finite or not. See e.g. the binomial series. Abel's theorem allows us to evaluate many series in closed form. For example, when

a k = ( − 1 ) k k + 1 , {\displaystyle a_{k}={\frac {(-1)^{k}}{k+1}},}

we obtain

G a ( z ) = ln ⁡ ( 1 + z ) z , 0 < z < 1 , {\displaystyle G_{a}(z)={\frac {\ln(1+z)}{z}},\qquad 0<z<1,}

by integrating the uniformly convergent geometric power series term by term on [ − z , 0 ] {\displaystyle [-z,0]} ; thus the series

∑ k = 0 ∞ ( − 1 ) k k + 1 {\displaystyle \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }{\frac {(-1)^{k}}{k+1}}}

converges to ln ⁡ ( 2 ) {\displaystyle \ln(2)} by Abel's theorem. Similarly,

∑ k = 0 ∞ ( − 1 ) k 2 k + 1 {\displaystyle \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }{\frac {(-1)^{k}}{2k+1}}}

converges to arctan ⁡ ( 1 ) = π 4 . {\displaystyle \arctan(1)={\tfrac {\pi }{4}}.}

G a ( z ) {\displaystyle G_{a}(z)} is called the generating function of the sequence a {\displaystyle a} . Abel's theorem is frequently useful in dealing with generating functions of real-valued and non-negative sequences, such as probability-generating functions. In particular, it is useful in the theory of Galton–Watson processes.

Outline of proof[edit]

After subtracting a constant from a 0 {\displaystyle a_{0}} , we may assume that ∑ k = 0 ∞ a k = 0 {\displaystyle \sum _{k=0}^{\infty }a_{k}=0} . Let s n = ∑ k = 0 n a k {\displaystyle s_{n}=\sum _{k=0}^{n}a_{k}\!} . Then substituting a k = s k − s k − 1 {\displaystyle a_{k}=s_{k}-s_{k-1}} and performing a simple manipulation of the series results in

G a ( z ) = ( 1 − z ) ∑ k = 0 ∞ s k z k . {\displaystyle G_{a}(z)=(1-z)\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }s_{k}z^{k}.}

Given ε > 0 , {\displaystyle \varepsilon >0,} pick n large enough so that | s k | < ε {\displaystyle |s_{k}|<\varepsilon } for all k ≥ n {\displaystyle k\geq n} and note that

| ( 1 − z ) ∑ k = n ∞ s k z k | ≤ ε | 1 − z | ∑ k = n ∞ | z | k = ε | 1 − z | | z | n 1 − | z | < ε M {\displaystyle \left|(1-z)\sum _{k=n}^{\infty }s_{k}z^{k}\right|\leq \varepsilon |1-z|\sum _{k=n}^{\infty }|z|^{k}=\varepsilon |1-z|{\frac {|z|^{n}}{1-|z|}}<\varepsilon M}

when z lies within the given Stolz angle. Whenever z is sufficiently close to 1 we have

| ( 1 − z ) ∑ k = 0 n − 1 s k z k | < ε , {\displaystyle \left|(1-z)\sum _{k=0}^{n-1}s_{k}z^{k}\right|<\varepsilon ,}

so that | G a ( z ) | < ( M + 1 ) ε {\displaystyle |G_{a}(z)|<(M+1)\varepsilon } when z is both sufficiently close to 1 and within the Stolz angle.

Related concepts[edit]

Converses to a theorem like Abel's are called Tauberian theorems: There is no exact converse, but results conditional on some hypothesis. The field of divergent series, and their summation methods, contains many theorems of abelian type and of tauberian type.
